Name: Mimikatz Execution
Notes: The specific modules would be at level two. The first selection is the name of the tool which can be changed easily on the command line.

Name: Turla Group Lateral Movement
Notes: This analytic is looking for basic strings and environment variables that will change over time.

Name: CobaltStrike Named Pipe Patterns
Notes: This analytic is looking for pipenames which can be changed like environment variables.

Name: Turla PNG Dropper Service
Notes: This uses an event ID 7045 to detect a new service being created with the name of "WerFaultSvc". While it is an uncommon service name, it can be easily changed by an adversary.

Name: Windows Binaries Write Suspicious Extensions
Notes: Depends on the target file name.

Name: New Outlook Macro Created
Notes: Depends on the target file name.

Name: Suspicious LNK Double Extension Files
Notes: Depends on the target file name.

Name: Potential Persistence Via Outlook Form
Notes: To evade this analytic, an adversary would need to modify the storage location of these forms within Outlook which is modifying a native tool. Therefore, this is out of the adversary's control and is a level 3 analytic.

Name: MSI Install from Suspicious Locations
Notes: Analytic is dependent on where the files originate, an observable which can be changed easily.

Name: Windows Vuln CVE 2021_41379
Notes: Looking for specific test package

Name: File Creation Date Changed to Another Year
Notes: Focused on specific time intervals and dates rather than the actual change behavior. Both selections act like filters to increase precision, they do not increase robustness.

Name: Diagnostic Library Sdiageng.DLL Loaded By Msdt.EXE
Notes: An adversary could evade this analytic by renaming both observables used.

Name: DirectorySearcher Powershell Exploitation
Notes: An adversary could obfuscate strings in the powershell script.

Name: Enumerate Credentials from Windows Credential Manager With PowerShell
Notes: The contains all statement includes an exact string that could be evaded with simple name changes. While the /listcreds commandline flag might score at a level 3 by itself, an adversary could obfuscate the string in their powershell script to evade the analytic.

Name: Suspicious Service DACL Modification Via Set-Service Cmdlet - PS
Notes: This is looking for the services name being changed in order to be more stealthy. However, these names are not unique and are simply what was used in the example used to create the analytic, they can be changed very easily.

Name: Moriya Rootkit File Created
Notes: The analytic is dependent on the target filename.

Name: Suspicious Chromium Browser Instance Executed with Custom Extensions
Notes: Analytic is dependent on parent image name.

Name: ISO File Created Within Temp Folders
Notes: Both selections in the analytic are dependent on a file path which can be changed to evade the analytic.

Name: Legitimate Application Dropped Archive
Notes: Analytic looking for Image name and file extension, both of which are observables that can be easily changed. If the program creating the ZIP file isn't explicitly named in the analytic, it won't fire.

Name: Vulnerable Driver Load
Notes: Hashes are operational variables that an adversary change fairly easily in most cases. See the Improved Analytic section for more detailed analysis.

Name: BloodHound Collection Files
Notes: Looks for file names that are in adversary control.

Name: HackTool - Mimikatz Execution
Notes: Analytic is looking for commandline arguments which are still within the adversaries control.

Name: Suspicious AdFind Execution
Notes: Analytic depends on the adfind.exe tool name.

Name: Suspicious PFX File Creation
Notes: File events restricted by targetfilenames

Name: New RUN Key Pointing to Suspicious Folder
Notes: Adversaries could bring their own filenames or change the name of the application

Name: Mimikatz Use
Notes: OR search that looks for values in the Keywords field. Most values are commandline flags for respective tools module which are in the adversary's control.

Name: Data Compressed - PowerShell
Notes: This would require changes to the script to evade but the adversary controls this action and script.

Name: Dump Credentials from Windows Credential Manager With PowerShell
Notes: Individual selections are looking at powershell commands which are part of the script block and in the adversary's control.

Name: Invoke-Obfuscation COMPRESS OBFUSCATION - PowerShell
Notes: This uses strings that could be within adversary control but not as simple as a file name to change.

Name: Clear PowerShell History - PowerShell
Notes: All of this is built-in powershell dependent.

Name: Suspicious PowerShell Download - Powershell Script
Notes: All observables  are dependent on  built-in powershell functionality.

Name: Suspicious Encoded Scripts in a WMI Consumer
Notes: This is looking for artifacts in a script within the adversary's control.

Name: Suspicious Access To Browser Credential Files
Notes: This relies on the configurations of the browser which are likely out of adversary control.

Name: Startup Folder File Write
Notes: This relies on a Windows default file location.

Name: Service Registry Permissions Weakness Check
Notes: This analytic is looking for the act of checking the permissions on a registry key. This check can be done  in many other ways, including ways that don't even involve PowerShell. See the Improved Analytic section for more info.

Name: Powershell File and Directory Discovery
Notes: These commands are all part of Powershell or Windows itself.

Name: WerFault LSASS Process Memory Dump
Notes: The filenames are default for the WerFault program, while lsass is also default for the proper configuration (outside of adversary control)

Name: WMI Persistence - Script Event Consumer File Write
Notes: Analytic is looking for behind-the-scenes OS behavior of WMI script handling which is outside adversary control.

Name: Persistence
Notes: This is based on native tools and their args.

Name: Direct Syscall of NtOpenProcess
Notes: Process Access is generated at kernel-mode, but CallTrace is within adversary control.

Name: MSI install from the web
Notes: The eventIds will be higher but the '://' is part of how the MsiInstaller gets its data and is outside of control.

Name: Possible Shadow Credentials Added
Notes: WEL Event ID running at kernel-level and the LDAPDisplayName value is central to  implementing technique, making the analytic difficult to evade.

Name: Windows Defender Threat Detected
Notes: Windows Defend Event IDs currently scored at OS API level (or higher). Can confirm with knowledge of if EventIDs are generated at user-mode or kernel-mode

Name: AADInternals PowerShell Cmdlets Execution - PsScript
Notes: Cmdlets could be renamed by an adversary.

Name: Suspicious Remote Thread Source
Notes: Create_remote_thread is Sysmon event 8. Most tools are native tools.

Name: Potential WinAPI Calls Via PowerShell Scripts
Notes: This is detecting the calling of OS API functions

Name: Windows Defender Malware Detection History Deletion
Notes: Because there is an event ID for the behavior, this is considered a very robust technique. Need confirmation the event code is fired from the OS API level or higher

Name: Backup Catalog Deleted
Notes: Microsoft documentation suggests that this is an OS-level application so it'd be a 5 at least.

Name: Eventlog Cleared
Notes: The eventID 104 is for 'The %3 log file was cleared' And when the provider name is that of the event log it would have been cleared. This looks to be dependent on the OS file locations.

Name: WMI Persistence
Notes: Changes to WMI subscriptions are well covered by a number of EventIDs and this takes advantage of that leading to a very difficult to evade analytic..

Name: Detect Credential Dumping through LSASS access
Notes: This analytic appears to cover all implementations of the subtechnique according to SpecterOps capability abstraction of Dumping LSASS. Process Access uses kernel-level APIs.
